finalPattern.pattern_name: Framing broadly relatable, real-world topics as myth-busting questions ("Do/Does X actually work?")—especially when they’re outliers from the channel’s usual physics niche—significantly boosts CTR and recommendations, driving 2–3x+ TPS versus baseline.

evidence.title: Do tire balancing beads actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Outlier/practical topic + skeptical question framing; 3.7M+ views vs channel baseline.

evidence.title: Do ceramic coatings actually work? (Torture test)
evidence.excerpt: Myth-busting question, mass-interest car-care topic, clear verdict testing.

evidence.title: Do vortex generators actually work on road cars?
evidence.excerpt: Applied engineering with a binary outcome promise increases click intent.

evidence.title: Do plug‑in energy savers actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Household device + skepticism format attracts broad audience.

evidence.title: Do fuel additives actually work? (Independent test)
evidence.excerpt: Commodity product + question framing + multi-metric testing.

evidence.title: Do rust converters actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Industrial-ish myth test with practical outcome, strong curiosity pull.

evidence.title: Do Airtabs actually work? Wind tunnel test
evidence.excerpt: Automotive aero gadget validated with visible testing apparatus.

evidence.title: Do magnetic phone chargers actually reduce wear?
evidence.excerpt: Consumer gadget framed as a testable claim drives broad interest.

evidence.title: Do air ionizers actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Health/household claim under skepticism format, clear payoff.

evidence.title: Do fuel line magnets actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Pseudoscience-adjacent claim tested with data; high CTR.

evidence.title: Do tire puncture sealants actually work?
evidence.excerpt: Same automotive category as beads; directly comparable interest profile.

evidence.title: Do anti-gravity devices actually work? (They don’t)
